lead_paragraph: The find seemed to settle a debate over whether the tools and ornaments found at archaeological sites belonged to modern humans or Neanderthals.

headline.print_headline: Humans Arrived in Europe Earlier, Teeth Suggest
headline.main: Teeth Tell of Earlier Trek to Europe by Humans

snippet: The find seemed to settle a debate over whether the tools and ornaments found at archaeological sites belonged to modern humans or Neanderthals.
abstract: Dr Stephano Benazzi study published in journal Science supports theory that first modern human immigrants arrived in Europe earlier than previously thought, perhaps at least 43,000 to 45,000 years ago; findings resulted from analysis of two teeth found in separate archaeological sites in Italy.
